title-group.article-title: The Influence of Lifestyle Behaviors and Body Mass Index Changes on Long-term Outcomes After Gastric Cancer Surgery: A Population-Based Cohort Study

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Surgery, Hanyang University College of Medicine, Seoul, Korea.
2Department of Pre-Medicine, College of Medicine, and Biostatistics Laboratory, Medical Research Collaborating Center, Hanyang University, Seoul, Korea.

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence to Ju-Hee Lee. Department of Surgery, Hanyang University College of Medicine, 222 Wangsimni-ro, Seongdong-gu, Seoul 04763, Korea. jhlee7979@hanyang.ac.kr

fn.p: *Ju-Hee Lee and Jiyeong Kim contributed equally to this study as co-first authors.

license.license-p: This is an Open Access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0) which permits unrestricted noncommercial use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.

sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: The present study investigated the impact of lifestyle behaviors and body mass index (BMI) on late recurrence, gastric remnant cancer (GRC), and long-term survival after curative gastrectomy.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: This retrospective study utilized data from the Korean National Health Insurance claims database. Among 71,014 patients with gastric cancer who underwent curative gastrectomy between January 2009 and December 2012, 23,359 remained cancer-free for five years. Of these, 7,735 patients with health examination data within 2 years before surgery and 5 years after surgery were analyzed for lifestyle behaviors, including smoking, alcohol consumption, and physical activity. Multivariable analysis was used to evaluate the independent effects of these factors and changes in BMI on late recurrence, GRC, and long-term survival.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Late recurrence or GRC occurred among 628 patients (8.1%). Older age (≥60 years) and total gastrectomy were identified as risk factors. Although lifestyle behaviors and BMI changes did not directly affect recurrence, they significantly affected mortality. In the total gastrectomy group, current underweight status (hazard ratio [HR], 1.586) was associated with increased mortality. Among the partial gastrectomy group, continued smoking (HR, 1.366) and current underweight status (HR, 1.915) increased mortality risk. Conversely, regular physical activity (starting: HR, 0.674; continuing: HR, 0.699) and postoperative overweight or obesity (BMI >25 kg/m2) (HR, 0.713) were associated with reduced mortality. Changes in alcohol consumption showed inconsistent effects between the partial and total gastrectomy groups.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The long-term survival of post-gastrectomy patients improved with smoking cessation, regular physical activity, and maintenance of body weight.

kwd-group.kwd: Late recurrence or gastric remnant cancer

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Despite the global decline, gastric cancer remains the fifth most common cancer [1]. Although systemic therapy improves the overall survival, radical resection remains the mainstay of treatment [23]. Though the role of postoperative follow-up in lengthening survival is ambiguous, it is crucial for managing post-gastrectomy syndrome and detecting early recurrences or secondary cancers [45]. Patients commonly seek guidance on lifestyle changes to prevent secondary cancers, including recurrence or gastric remnant cancer (GRC), for improving long-term outcomes.

Global organizations like the International Agency for Research on Cancer and the World Cancer Research Fund International regularly update the evidence for gastric cancer risk factors [6]. Sufficient evidence exists for the risk factors for primary gastric cancer, including Helicobacter pylori infection, smoking, industrial chemical exposure, excess body fat (cardia cancer), alcohol consumption, and salt-preserved food. However, risk factors with limited evidence include processed meat (noncardia), grilled (broiled) or barbecued (charbroiled) meat and fish, low fruit intake, nitrate or nitrite (ingested) under conditions that result in endogenous nitrosamine formation, and pickled vegetables [7]. Primary prevention of gastric cancer involves preventing the occurrence of these risk factors. Although physicians utilize the existing evidence to provide guidance on lifestyle modifications during postoperative follow-up, the literature on their effect on long-term survival outcomes among gastric cancer survivors remains limited, indicating the need for targeted studies on lifestyle impacts after gastrectomy.

Covering 97% of the population, the National Health Insurance Service (NHIS) in Korea requires all insured adults aged >40 years to undergo biennial health screenings. The Korean National Health Screening Program (NHSP) assesses various lifestyle factors and body measurements. Therefore, we utilized the Korean NHIS and NHSP databases to evaluate the likely influence of lifestyle behaviors and body weight changes before and after gastric cancer surgery on the occurrence of late recurrence or GRC and suggest appropriate post-gastrectomy follow-up strategies to ensure long-term survival through lifestyle modifications.

sec.title: Data source and study population
sec.p: The present study utilized the Korean NHIS claims data from 2008 to 2021 and NHSP data from 2009 to 2017. The NHIS claims database included information about patients’ demographic characteristics, type of health insurance, diagnosis based on the International Classification of Diseases (ICD), date of hospital visits, prescriptions received during inpatient and outpatient visits, hospital admissions, medical and surgical procedures, and medical expenses. The NHSP data included a health behavior questionnaire (smoking, alcohol consumption, diet pattern, and exercise), a medical history questionnaire, and information on physical examinations such as height and weight, laboratory studies, and chest radiography.

Supplementary Fig. 1 displays the study sample selection process. Data from 71,014 patients who underwent curative gastrectomy for gastric cancer (ICD-10 code C16 and cancer registration code V193) between 2009 and 2012 were extracted from the Korean NHI claims database. Patients with a 5-year cancer-free status after curative gastric cancer surgery were selected using the following exclusion criteria: 1) those who died within 5 years after gastrectomy (n=15,460), 2) those who underwent additional gastrectomy or endoscopic resection due to GRC between 1 month and 5 years after primary gastrectomy (n=320), and 3) those who received chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy due to recurrent gastric cancer between 1 and 5 years after primary gastrectomy (n=27,282). Additionally, 4,593 patients diagnosed with other forms of cancer within 5 years after primary gastrectomy were excluded. Among the remaining 23,359 patients, 7,735 who underwent a health examination within 2 years before gastrectomy and 5 years after gastrectomy were included in the final analysis.

sec.title: Lifestyle factors and body mass index (BMI)
sec.p: The examination items in the NHSP database underwent several revisions; therefore, only variables whose consistency was confirmed for comparison before and after gastrectomy were utilized in the present study. Thus, data on smoking, alcohol consumption, physical activity, and BMI from 2009 to 2017 were used, whereas data on dietary habits, such as salt and meat intake, were unavailable. Standardized self-reported questionnaires were used to collect data on patients’ smoking status, alcohol consumption, and physical activity performance [8]. Smoking status was categorized as follows: never smoker (nonsmoking both before and after surgery), previous smoker (stopped smoking after gastrectomy), current smoker (nonsmoker before gastrectomy), and continuing smoker (smoking both before and after surgery). As alcohol consumption was surveyed by weekly frequency instead of amount, it was categorized as never drinking, stopped drinking, drinking less than before surgery, and drinking the same as or more than before surgery. BMI (kg/m2) was classified into underweight (<18.5 kg/m2), normal weight (18.5–25 kg/m2), and overweight or obese (>25.0 kg/m2). BMI changes were categorized as follows: staying normal, normalization from obesity, currently underweight (regardless of previous status), and currently overweight or obese (from previously obese or normal weight). None of the patients who were preoperatively underweight achieved normal weight or became obese postoperatively. Based on the guidelines for exercise testing and prescription, regular physical activity was defined as engaging in moderate physical activity at least five times per week or vigorous physical activity at least three times per week [9]. Physical activity was classified into four groups: 1) remained without regular physical activity, 2) started regular physical activity (after surgery), 3) quit regular physical activity, and 4) continued regular physical activity. Supplementary Table 1 presents detailed information on the definitions of lifestyle variables.

sec.title: Covariates
sec.p: Patients’ characteristics included age at the time of surgery, sex, health insurance type (NHI or Medical Aid program), type of surgery (partial or total gastrectomy), laparoscopic surgery, adjuvant chemotherapy, H. pylori eradication, and Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI). The diagnosis, procedure, and prescription codes related to the study variables are shown in Supplementary Tables 2 and 3. Chemotherapy was defined as the presence of procedure codes for chemotherapeutic agent injection and/or prescription of oral chemotherapeutic drug S1 or capecitabine. Adjuvant treatment was defined as chemotherapy performed within 1 year after primary gastrectomy. H. pylori eradication was defined as receiving a prescription for standard triple therapy (a combination of a proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin) or bismuth-based quadruple therapy (a combination of bismuth, metronidazole, tetracycline, and a proton pump inhibitor) for 7–14 days. The CCI score at the time of surgery was calculated based on the presence of relevant diagnoses recorded within one year before primary gastrectomy [10]. The 5-year postoperative CCI score was calculated by adding the weights of newly diagnosed conditions during the 5-year follow-up period.

sec.title: Outcomes
sec.p: The occurrence of late recurrence or GRC was defined as hospitalization or an outpatient clinic visit for gastric cancer with a V193 code (active cancer registration code) 5 years after gastrectomy. The registration of the V193 code was removed in the absence of evidence indicating cancer 5 years after the initial registration [11]. Therefore, the presence of the V193 code 5 years post-gastrectomy indicated the occurrence of a new cancer. The first hospitalization or an outpatient clinic visit after 5 years of gastrectomy was defined as the timing of late recurrence or GRC. The presence of ICD-10 C codes along with the V193 code indicated the development of any type of malignancy. Survival analysis utilized follow-up data until December 31, 2021. The patient was considered alive in the absence of mortality data until the last follow-up date. The median follow-up period was 134.5 months (range, 62.6–169.9 months).

sec.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
sec.p: The Institutional Review Board (IRB) of Hanyang University Hospital (IRB protocol approval number: HYUH-2022-11-049) approved the study. The requirement for informed consent was waived since anonymized data were obtained from the NHIS.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Analyses were performed using the SAS Enterprise Guide Software 7.1 (SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA) and R version 4.0.3 (R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria). Duplicate clinical data with identical codes were excluded and considered as a single case. Participants’ demographic characteristics were analyzed using the mean ± standard deviation (range) or frequencies and percentages. Groups were compared using chi-squared, Fisher’s exact, and independent Student’s t-tests. Survival was calculated using the Kaplan–Meier method and compared using the log-rank test. Cox proportional hazards regression was used to determine the independent risk factors associated with the occurrence of late recurrence or GRC and any type of malignancy, and prognostic factors associated with overall survival in disease-free survivors >5 years after gastrectomy. Even if one aspect of a factor showed a significant P-value, all details of that factor were included in the multivariate analysis. Statistical significance was set at a two-tailed P-value <0.05.

sec.title: Characteristics of the study population
sec.p: Table 1 shows the patients’ characteristics. Among the 7,735 patients who met the inclusion criteria, 70.1% (n=5,419) were male and 29.9% (n=2,316) were female. Patients’ average age was 59.0±10.4 years at the time of surgery, ranging from 26 to 90 years. Regarding the insurance type, 99.9% (n=7,725) were covered under health insurance, whereas only 0.1% (n=10) were covered under medical aid. The majority of the surgeries performed were partial gastrectomy (84.4%, n=6,527), followed by total gastrectomy (15.6%, n=1,208). Following gastrectomy, H. pylori eradication was performed among only 2.1% of the patients (n=160). Laparoscopic surgery was performed among 43.2% (n=3,338) of the patients. About 44.9% (n=3,471) of the patients received adjuvant chemotherapy. Late recurrence or GRC occurred in 8.1% (n=628) of the patients. Additionally, 7.7% (n=592) of the patients were diagnosed with other cancers more than 5 years after gastrectomy. The mean CCI score at the time of surgery was 3.8±1.4. The CCI scores were distributed as follows: 11.1% (n=856) scored less than 2, 65.6% (n=5,073) scored between 3 and 4, and 23.4% (n=1,806) scored 5 or above. The mean CCI score increased to 4.5±1.8 5 years after gastrectomy. At this point, 6.7% (n=515) of the patients had CCI scores less than 2, 53.7% (n=4,155) scored between 3 and 4, and 39.6% (n=3,065) scored 5 or above.

tr.td: Occurrence of late recurrence or GRC
Occurrence of other cancers (5 years post-gastrectomy)
CCI scores at the time of surgery (mean ± SD)
CCI scores at the time of surgery

table-wrap-foot.p: Values are presented as number (%) unless otherwise indicated.SD = standard deviation; GRC = gastric remnant cancer; CCI = Charlson comorbidity index

sec.title: Impact of lifestyle behaviors on the incidence of late recurrence or GRC or secondary malignancy
sec.p: The prevalence of current smoking decreased from 28.5% before surgery to 11.8% after surgery (Supplementary Table 4). The prevalence of alcohol consumption decreased from 49.3% before surgery to 32.5% after surgery.

In the univariable analysis, factors associated with an increased incidence of late recurrence or GRC included age ≥60 years, total gastrectomy, open surgery (vs. laparoscopy), and normalized BMI from overweight or obesity (Table 2). Multivariable analysis revealed age ≥60 years and total gastrectomy as independent factors influencing the incidence of late recurrence or GRC. Not all lifestyle behaviors were associated with the incidence of late recurrence or GRC.

caption.title: Risk factors associated with late recurrence or GRC in GC survivors >5 years post-gastrectomy

table-wrap-foot.p: GRC = gastric remnant cancer; GC = gastric cancer; CI = confidence interval; BMI = body mass index.

sec.p: Supplementary Table 5 presents the list of other cancers that occurred after 5 years of gastrectomy. The risk factors associated with an increased incidence of secondary malignancies (including late recurrence and GRC) were analyzed (Table 3). The univariable analysis revealed that the increased incidence of secondary malignancy was associated with male sex, older age (≥60 years), total gastrectomy, and continued smoking. While the multivariable analysis determined male sex (hazard ratio [HR] for females, 0.838 [95% confidence interval [CI], 0.717–0.981]), age ≥60 years, previous smoking, and continued smoking as independent risk factors associated with the occurrence of secondary malignancy (HR, 1.705 [95% CI, 1.493–1.948]; 1.202 [95% CI, 1.012–1.426]; 1.326 [95% CI, 1.078–1.631], respectively).

caption.title: Risk factors associated with the occurrence of secondary cancers in GC survivors >5 years post-gastrectomy

table-wrap-foot.p: GC = gastric cancer; CI = confidence interval; BMI = body mass index.

sec.title: Factors associated with overall survival in disease-free survivors >5 years after partial gastrectomy
sec.p: The univariable analysis revealed sex, age (<60 vs. ≥60 years), use of a laparoscopic approach during the initial resection, administration of adjuvant chemotherapy after surgery, occurrence of secondary cancers, CCI scores at the time of surgery, changes or consistency in smoking habits (Fig. 1A), alcohol consumption (Fig. 1B), physical activity (BMI) (Fig. 1C), and BMI (Fig. 1D) (Table 4) as the factors associated with overall survival. In the multivariable analysis, factors associated with increased overall mortality included male sex (HR for female, 0.513 [95% CI, 0.416–0.632], age ≥60 years (HR, 3.674 [95% CI, 3.004–4.495]), history of adjuvant chemotherapy (HR, 1.199 [95% CI, 1.037–1.385]), occurrence of secondary malignancies (HR, 4.168 [95% CI, 3.590–4.839]), and higher CCI scores at the time of surgery (HR for CCI 3–4, 1.871 [95% CI, 1.338–2.616]; HR for CCI ≥5, 2.543 [95% CI, 1.802–3.591]). Additionally, higher mortality was associated with continued smoking (HR, 1.366 [95% CI, 1.097–1.702]), and current underweight status (HR, 1.915 [95% CI, 1.573-2.330]). While continuous alcohol consumption did not affect mortality, regular physical activity was associated with reduced mortality when it was initiated (HR, 0.674 [95% CI, 0.539–0.844]) and maintained (HR, 0.699 [95% CI, 0.530–0.922]).

caption.title: Overall survival curve in gastric cancer survivors who underwent partial gastrectomy according to modified lifestyle factors: (A) Smoking. (B) Alcohol consumption. (C) Physical activity. (D) Body mass index.
Factors associated with overall survival in GC survivors >5 years after partial gastrectomy

tr.td: CCI at the time of surgery

table-wrap-foot.p: GC = gastric cancer; CI = confidence interval; CCI = Charlson comorbidity index; BMI = body mass index.

sec.title: Factors associated with overall survival in disease-free survivors >5 years after total gastrectomy
sec.p: The univariable analysis revealed that sex, age (<60 vs. ≥60 years), occurrence of secondary cancers, CCI scores at the time of surgery, changes or consistency in smoking habits (Fig. 2A), alcohol consumption (Fig. 2B), and BMI (Fig. 2D) (Table 5) as factors associated with overall survival. Unlike partial gastrectomy, changes or consistency in physical activity were not associated with overall survival (Fig. 2C). the multivariable analysis indicated that increased mortality was associated with male sex (HR for female, 0.552 [95% CI, 0.357–0.855]), age ≥60 years (HR, 2.301[95% CI, 1.607–3.295]), occurrence of secondary malignancies (HR, 3.543 [95% CI, 2.582–4.862]), CCI ≥5 (HR, 1.962 [95% CI, 1.063–3.620]), and current underweight status (HR, 1.586 [95% CI, 1.096–2.296]). Reduced alcohol consumption was linked to decreased mortality (HR, 0.242 [95% CI, 0.112–0.524]).

caption.title: Overall survival curve in gastric cancer survivors who underwent total gastrectomy according to modified lifestyle factors: (A) Smoking. (B) Alcohol consumption. (C) Physical activity. (D) Body mass index.
Factors associated with overall survival in GC survivors >5 years after total gastrectomy

tr.td: CCI at the time of surgery

table-wrap-foot.p: GC = gastric cancer; CI = confidence interval; BMI = body mass index.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Physicians commonly educate patients to modify their lifestyle behaviors associated with the development of gastric cancer during postoperative follow-up. However, no previous study has investigated the advantages of lifestyle modifications in preventing secondary cancers, including recurrence or GRC, and their impact on long-term survival. The present study findings revealed that continuous smoking and persistent or newly developed underweight status after surgery were associated with poor long-term survival among patients who successfully underwent primary gastric cancer treatment. Furthermore, regular physical activity was associated with long-term survival benefits. Since the number of long-terms survivors have increased owing to the advancements in gastric cancer treatment, it is crucial to educate patients regarding these aspects during follow-up.

Approximately 11% of gastric cancer cases are attributed to smoking [12]. A study in Japan found higher risks for developing gastric cancer among current and past smokers, with relative risks of 1.84 and 1.77, respectively [13]. The increased risk was associated with the number of cigarettes smoked and pack-years. Among past smokers, the risk remained elevated for up to 14 years after smoking cessation. A European study found similar risks, which diminished 10 years after cessation [14]. In the present study, changes in smoking habit were not associated with the incidence of late recurrence or GRC. However, the risk of secondary malignancies was higher in both the previous and continuous smoking groups. The risk of secondary cancer did not increase among current smokers (nonsmokers before surgery) possibly due to their relatively shorter smoking history. Additionally, patients who ceased smoking after surgery showed overall survival rates that were not different from those of patients who never smoked. Although the exact timing of smoking cessation is unknown, patients were assumed to have quit smoking immediately after gastric cancer surgery based on the habits of the general patient population. Therefore, although a prolonged smoking abstinence is required to prevent secondary cancer, smoking abstinence for more than 5 years can enhance long-term survival.

Underweight status contributes to mortality in the general population [15]. Weight loss after gastric cancer surgery is a common phenomenon. However, the extent of weight loss after gastrectomy depends on the preoperative BMI and the extent of gastric resection [16]. Maximum weight change was observed at 6–12 months after surgery, which remained stable or improved at 2 years. The present study showed that if weight loss that does not improve continues even 5 years after surgery, mortality can increase in both total and partial gastrectomy patients. Therefore, postoperative follow-up should emphasize on preventing weight loss through frequent weight checks, appropriate dietary education, and nutritional supplements [17].

Contradictory epidemiological evidence exists for the association between alcohol consumption and stomach cancer [18192021]. Compared to the group who have never consumed alcohol, those who have consumed alcohol show an association with an increased risk of cardia gastric cancer. However, no significant association has been observed with noncardia gastric cancer [22]. Moreover, heavy alcohol consumption has been associated with a higher risk of both cardia and noncardia gastric cancers when compared to individuals who have never consumed alcohol [23]. According to the present study, alcohol consumption did not influence the occurrence of secondary malignancy, including late recurrence or GRC, and did not increase mortality. However, the analysis did not include the alcohol amount because the variable classification was based on the change in the frequency of alcohol consumption per week before and after surgery owing to the large amount of missing data on alcohol consumption. Furthermore, the present study excluded 15,624 patients who did not undergo health examinations 5 years after gastrectomy. Consequently, the cohort used in this study likely included patients who were more health-conscious and maintained better overall health with potentially lower levels of harmful alcohol consumption. In contrast, those excluded from the study may have engaged in higher alcohol consumption, introducing a potential selection bias. Alcohol consumption is a modifiable risk factor, its reduction or elimination can help reduce the risk of other related health issues. Further research is required to verify these findings.

This study had several limitations. It was an observational study utilizing the NHI claims database. The database lacked detailed clinical information, such as the cancer stage, H. pylori infection status, and family history, which may affect recurrence or GRC. Most stomach cancers recur within five years after surgery, which undermines the impact of the cancer stage on survival or recurrence beyond five years after surgery. H. pylori infection rates would be inaccurate even with clinical data unless the study is prospective. Familial gastric cancer history is relatively rare in Korea, accounting for 0.3%–3.1% [24]. Second, information on lifestyle behaviors were self-reported, which may have introduced recall bias. Additionally, the study only compared two time points, thereby limiting longitudinal behavioral evaluation. Third, smoking duration and amount, amount of alcohol consumption, and salt and meat intake could not be analyzed due to missing data. Fourth, the exclusion of a large proportion of participants (15,624 of 23,359; 66.9%) lacking health examination data during the study period may have introduced selection bias. Additionally, patients who underwent endoscopic resection for stage I gastric cancer and long-term survivors of stage IV gastric cancer were excluded. Despite these limitations, this is the first study to evaluate the impact of modifiable lifestyle factors on late recurrence or GRC and long-term survival. Its strength resides in the large patient sample and use of population-based data, enabling the analysis of long-term outcomes with no attrition.

The study findings revealed that the occurrence of late recurrence or GRC in survivors after more than five years of gastric cancer surgery was not independently influenced by lifestyle modifications. However, smoking after surgery and a persistent underweight status were associated with poor long-term survival, whereas regular physical activity was associated with reduced mortality. Postoperative follow-ups should emphasize the maintenance of body weight, promote smoking cessation, and encourage regular physical activity.

fn.p: Funding: The Korean Gastric Cancer Association (No. KGCA012022R1) provided funding for this study.
Conflict of Interest: No potential conflict of interest relevant to this article was reported.
